Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: How Does Environmental Change Influence Landscape Evolution in the Pantanal Wetlands (Brazil)?
Award.AbstractNarration:
A non-technical description of the project, which explains the project's significance and importance

The Pantanal region of Brazil is a vast domain of headwater wetlands that represents a little-documented aspect in the evolution of river systems. These environments are extremely important for the ecological health of tropical rivers. The environment is sensitive to both climatic and environmental changes, but the degree to which these will affect the region is unknown. This project will examine lake cores collected from the region to establish a chronology of environmental change in the region that documents the response of the system to climate and can help evaluate the possible effects of human intervention. This is a collaborative project that is co-funded by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

A technical description of the project

This RAPID project will examine how changing environmental conditions can (1) impact surface processes (e.g., erosion and weathering); and (2) influence landscape evolution in lowland tropical wetlands. The field site is the little- studied Pantanal of central South America. The Brazilian Pantanal offers an excellent example of extensive savanna-floodplain wetland development along several coalescing megafans (large distributive fluvial systems). The main objective of this research is to collect new lake sediment cores from a large floodplain lake in the northern Pantanal. Lake deposits are a potential archive of Quaternary landscape evolution, as the dynamics of sediment composition and accumulation are sensitive to environmental transitions. The project will use standard techniques to assess how the lake accumulates sediment today, and use these data as a framework for interpreting older material recovered from the lake cores.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Numerically dated lake sediments provide a lens through which the effects of climate change and human land use on landscape evolution can be viewed.  This RAPID project took advantage of a convergence in unusual access to sampling permits, a timely weather window, and personnel in Brazil to sample the largest lake in the Pantanal wetlands, Lake Uberaba. The Pantanal is one of the world’s premier sites to study the Quaternary evolution of large distributive fluvial systems (DFSs) and lowland wetlands in a tropical setting. The importance of DFSs to the rock record remains a topic of considerable debate that has implications for accurate interpretations of Earth history, lowland biogeography, and fluid flow in the critical zone.  Perhaps more important, the Pantanal’s DFSs host extensive wetlands, which are critical to: (a) the global carbon cycle; (b) patterns of Neotropical biodiversity; and (c) sustaining human lives by providing valuable ecosystem services. The savanna floodplains of the Pantanal have captured the attention of geomorphologists and ecohydrologists for decades, but the vast majority of research concerning landscape evolution has been founded on the analysis of remotely sensed data. The reliance on remote sensing stems largely from practical concerns – the Pantanal is formidable wilderness – and access to permits from the Brazilian government are very difficult for foreigners to obtain.  

The project team, comprised of scientists and students from the USA and Brazil (Federal University of Mato Grosso do Sul), completed the first successful sampling expeditions to the Lake Uberaba region of northwestern Pantanal, which is situated along the toe of the Paraguay DFS.  The project PIs built collaborations with the Brazilian Army and the Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation, who provided logistical support that helped to make the sampling expeditions possible, as well as access to new remote sensing and environmental time series datasets. As the lake was previously unexplored, the approach initially focused on sampling to understand the limnogeology of the modern system, in order to constrain the hydroclimate filter imposed by the lake on any environmental reconstructions made using sediment cores. An extensive bathymetric sounding survey was completed, which revealed the depth structure of the lake and highlighted the influence of inflowing axial and lateral rivers on the shallow, hydrologically open lake basin. These insights were confirmed by a shallow seismic profile, which imaged a low-relief floodplain with incised channels underlying the lake system. In situ physical/chemical properties (dissolved oxygen, pH, temperature, salinity) were measured at the air-water and water-mud boundaries, which revealed a well-mixed, oxygenated, freshwater lake basin.  Discrete water samples were measured for major ion chemistry, which confirmed a dilute lake. An extensive grid of modern sediment samples was collected in order to assess modern facies and to use for context for interpreting changes in depositional environment captured by sediment cores. The modern sediments offshore are highly oxidized sandy silts with minor amounts of organic carbon and moderate biogenic silica. Nearshore sediments are characterized by finer grain sizes and higher organic carbon content.  Inflowing rivers and waves exert the largest controls on patterns of sediment accumulation in the modern lake, and zones of uninterrupted sedimentation by suspension settling are uncommon.  Sediment cores (n=8) were recovered from several different areas of the lake floor.  Cores from the deepest areas of the lake contain two facies suites - a younger, hydrologically open lacustrine assemblage and an older, sub-aerially exposed floodplain assemblage. Sediments from the floodplain facies assemblage are oxidized and mudcracked silty clays, which provide compelling evidence for an important aquatic transition along the toe of the Paraguay DFS in the recent past. The well-mixed nature of the extent lake precludes a high resolution hydroclimatic reconstruction from Uberaba, but chronological data currently under development suggest that the largest lake in the Pantanal formed in the very recent past, perhaps no more than a few hundred years ago, at a time of intense local rainfall. Sedimentation rate data, coupled with analyses of satellite images, suggest that the open water area of Lake Uberaba is currently shrinking, and that lakes and wetlands along the toe of the Paraguay DFS may evolve into different landforms in the near future.  Data collected during the project period therefore enhance our knowledge of how and at what pace DFSs change, and the key boundary conditions that control their evolution. In addition, the project sets the stage for constraining the rates at which different lake types fill in within the Pantanal, which represents an important quantitative step forward in our understanding of the evolution of floodplain lakes, which has profound implications for biogeochemical cycling, habitat development, and water resources. The project trained four students (two in the USA, two in Brazil), provided mentoring opportunities for two early career scientists, and strengthened international scientific collaboration between two universities and a federally-sponsored research organization.
